name: places/ChIJd_REgAhZwokRNpR6B6H_nfc
formattedAddress: 160 E 34th St, New York, NY 10016, USA
adrFormatAddress: 160 E 34th St, New York, NY 10016-4744, USA

originalText.text: This is a great place which has kept me alive and I am so grateful. As a stage 4 patient, I only wish the doctors would stop talking about death and preparing me for it so much. Just wish they would address the issue as a survival rate as opposed to death. It would make the experience a little lighter but I suppose thats how they must address cancer patients. The nurses are excellent on the chemotherapy floor and they want to make your experience very comfortable. The chemotherapy nurses are kind and inspiring♥️

text.text: This is a great place which has kept me alive and I am so grateful. As a stage 4 patient, I only wish the doctors would stop talking about death and preparing me for it so much. Just wish they would address the issue as a survival rate as opposed to death. It would make the experience a little lighter but I suppose thats how they must address cancer patients. The nurses are excellent on the chemotherapy floor and they want to make your experience very comfortable. The chemotherapy nurses are kind and inspiring♥️

originalText.text:
Not sure.  A friend was diagnosed with cancer there recently.
The first thing they do is radiology, if they see what they think is cancer, then they schedule a biopsy.   This is BEFORE you get to see an oncologist.
After the biopsy, my friend was told they would need to have surgery.
And unbelievably., my friend still was told that they would see the oncologist
AFTER the surgery.    So to make sure that the surgeon removes the cancer from the right place, they put in a probe.  But, then the surgeon discovered that the other doctor put the probe in the wrong place, and it was not even noted on the  medical record.  Good that was caught, but  now they have to do it again .  And yes, they still have not seen the oncologist.     My friend is wondering now if they should trust NYU with the further treatment of their cancer.   And of course, NYU billed the insurance literally seconds after each procedure, even the one they messed up.

originalText.text: Kept very clean and organized. Lobby has temperature check in and must have appointment. Very well lit and information desk right as you walk in. Valet parking as very busy street and few metered spaces.
